awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to prepare reactants and control products on demand with quantum state precision is a long cherished goal in chemistry. This goal is increasingly becoming achievable thanks to the progress in recent years in cooling and trapping molecules and controlled manipulation of their interactions at temperatures close to absolute zero. The fundamental question of how chemical reactions proceed at a collision energy close to absolute zero can now be explored both by experiment and theory. Such controlled manipulation of atoms and molecules is an integral part of current research in quantum technologies, including quantum information processing and quantum computing. Theoretical studies of molecular encounters in this area face significant obstacles as computations become intractable when all relevant quantum states and external field effects are included. The goal of this NSF award is to develop and implement new methodologies to study ultracold chemical reactions with full quantum state resolution of both reactants and products. The research may lead to new computational programs capable of describing chemical reactions at ultracold temperatures. The research crosses disciplinary boundaries in diverse areas of chemistry, physics, and astrophysics and develops a highly skilled science and engineering workforce. 

An ultimate goal in chemistry is the complete control of quantum states of both reactants and products with high selectivity and specificity.  The quantum state resolution applies both to the internal states of the molecules and the angular momentum partial waves involved in the collision process. Restricting partial waves requires reducing the collision energy to a kelvin or below for most molecular systems. Even in this regime, electronically non-adiabatic and geometric phase effects play an important role in governing the outcome of a chemical reaction. However, such processes remain largely unexplored in the utracold regime. The main goal of this NSF Award is to develop new methodologies and computer codes to study electronically non-adiabatic effects in chemical reactions at cold and ultracold temperatures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We are in the midst of a second quantum revolution with a goal of controlling and manipulating isolated or ensemble of atoms/molecules/ions for new computing, sensing, and communication applications. Such control requires precise knowledge of how atoms and molecules interact with each other and with light (photons) as well as how their properties are modified by exposing them to an external electric or magnetic fields. This is a rapidly expanding field with nation states and global companies investing billions of dollars in a race to reach quantum supremacy. Quantum computers and communication systems are no longer limited to science fiction novels/movies but are rapidly becoming a reality. Progress in these areas have immensely benefited from fundamental molecular level understanding of how atoms and molecules interact and how their interaction can be harnessed by external electric, magnetic and optical fields. Such control requires very low temperatures, often in the micro-Kelvin and nano-Kelvin temperature regimes (referred to as ultracold) where quantum effects dominate. Because an accurate description of atomic and molecular interactions requires a quantum mechanical treatment, quantum calculations have become an integral part of this new quantum revolution. This also presents exciting opportunities to study chemistry in a regime dominated by quantum effects and ultracold chemistry has become an exciting area of experimental and theoretical interrogation in recent years. 

The award led to several quantum mechanical investigations of chemical reactions as well as molecular energy transfer processes in the cold and ultracold regimes. It has generally been accepted that most chemical reactions occur through the ground electronic state and the effect of the excited electronic states is not important at low collision energies. However, for alkali metal trimer systems such as K+KRb and Li+LiNa the first excited electronic state undergoes a conical intersection with the ground electronic state and it is accessible through collisions occurring from the ground state even in the limit of ultracold collision energies. Thus, a realistic description of chemical reactivity in these systems should also include non-adiabatic coupling with the excited state. Such calculations are computationally demanding and undertaken for the first time with support of this award for the Li+LiNa chemical reaction leading to Li2+Na product. It has been found that conical intersection with the excited electronic state leads to a novel interference mechanism. When this interference is constructive the reaction is enhanced and when it is destructive the reaction is suppressed. Maximum constructive and destructive interference occurs in the ultracold regime (due to isotropic scattering) allowing full control of the reaction outcome. In the course of this award, we have also explored other ways of controlling reaction outcomes, such as controlling the alignment of the bond-axis of the reactant molecule relative to the collision velocity. Such control through alignment (stereodynamics) has recently been demonstrated in the group of Richard Zare and coworkers at Stanford for rotational quenching in atom-dimer and dimer-dimer collisions and we have theoretically addressed this topic for several molecular systems, including those studied by Zare and collaborators. Altogether, the award led to 14 peer-reviewed publications in overlapping areas of physics, chemistry and astrophysics and provided partial support for two postdoctoral scholars.
